article_content:
In the rapidly evolving landscape of software development and app creation, integrating tools and structured workflows has become essential for enhancing coding quality. The Cursor Composer Tool stands at the forefront of this AI coding revolution, offering a powerful platform that streamlines the development process and improves the standard of code production.

AI-assisted coding is not just about automation; it’s about augmenting human capabilities to create more efficient, precise, and innovative solutions. By strategically incorporating AI into your workflow, you can transform your approach to software development, tackling complex projects with unprecedented ease and accuracy.

Breaking Down Tasks for Optimal AI Implementation

One of the key strategies in using AI for coding is the systematic breakdown of tasks. This approach allows for more focused and effective AI implementation, making sure that each component of your project receives the attention it deserves. Consider the following benefits:

Enhanced precision in code generation

Improved efficiency in task completion

Better alignment with project objectives

Easier identification and resolution of issues

For instance, when working on a complex project like a podcast transcript editor, breaking down tasks becomes crucial. You might segment the project into distinct phases such as user authentication, transcript processing, and interface design. This granular approach allows AI to focus on specific aspects, like implementing detailed permission controls, making sure that only authorized users can access certain features.

5x Your Coding Quality

Here are a selection of other guides from our extensive library of content you may find of interest on the subject of AI Coding :

The Synergy of Human Oversight and AI Capabilities

While AI can generate code with remarkable speed and accuracy, the role of human developers remains indispensable. Your expertise is crucial in guiding and refining AI outputs, making sure they align with the project’s overall vision and requirements. This synergy between human insight and AI capabilities leads to superior code quality and more innovative solutions.

Testing and debugging play a pivotal role in this process. By rigorously evaluating AI-generated code, you can:

Identify and rectify potential issues early in the development cycle

Ensure functionality aligns with project specifications

Maintain high standards of code reliability and performance

Adapt AI outputs to specific project needs and constraints

Using Context for Enhanced AI Performance

Providing comprehensive context to AI is crucial for optimal performance. By giving AI a thorough understanding of your codebase and project requirements, you enable it to generate more accurate and relevant code. Tools like Cursor Rules and Notepads are invaluable in this regard, helping maintain consistency and making sure that AI tasks are perfectly aligned with your project’s objectives.

This contextual approach is particularly beneficial when dealing with complex systems or when integrating new features into existing projects. It allows AI to consider the broader implications of code changes, leading to more seamless integrations and fewer conflicts.

The Importance of End-to-End Testing

End-to-end testing is a critical component in making sure the quality and reliability of AI-assisted coding projects. Tools like Playwright offer comprehensive testing capabilities, allowing you to:

Verify the functionality of new features in real-world scenarios

Ensure seamless integration with existing systems

Identify and address potential user experience issues

Validate the overall performance and stability of your application

By implementing thorough end-to-end testing, you not only catch bugs but also ensure that the user experience remains consistent and high-quality across all aspects of your application.

Structured Coding Workflows: The Foundation of Quality

Adopting structured coding workflows is fundamental to maintaining high code quality. These workflows provide a systematic approach to development, encompassing planning, implementation, testing, and refinement stages. By adhering to best practices and established methodologies, you create a robust framework that supports:

Consistent code quality across team members and projects

Easier maintenance and scalability of codebases

Improved collaboration and knowledge sharing within teams

Faster onboarding of new team members or project contributors

Structured workflows also assist better integration of AI tools, making sure that these powerful resources are used effectively and in alignment with your project’s goals.

Enhancing coding quality through AI tools and structured workflows represents a significant leap forward in software development. By using platforms like the Cursor Composer Tool, breaking down tasks effectively, and implementing rigorous testing and refinement processes, you can achieve remarkable improvements in efficiency, accuracy, and innovation in your projects. This approach not only improves the quality of your code but also positions you at the cutting edge of software development practices, ready to tackle the challenges of tomorrow’s technological landscape.

title: Familia.AI Launches AI Family App Creating Supportive Family Members, Reconnecting Lost Loved Ones, and Preserving Legacies
description: Familia.AI Launches Revolutionary AI-Powered Family App San Francisco, California--( - October 11, 2024) - Familia.AI ...
article_content:
Familia.AI Launches Revolutionary AI-Powered Family App

San Francisco, California--(Newsfile Corp. - October 11, 2024) - Familia.AI (familia.ai) today unveiled its groundbreaking AI family app, allowing users to create and interact with AI-powered family members, preserving family legacies, and enhancing family dynamics through digital connections that span generations.

Familia.AI - Creating AI Family App



To view an enhanced version of this graphic, please visit:

https://images.newsfilecorp.com/files/10373/226387_e29ed86cb4d098f7_001full.jpg

"Familia AI empowers users to both create and interact with AI-powered family members they may not have had in real life, offering emotional support as well as creating AI family members from aging or passed real family members," said Rohan Sinclair Luvaglio, Familia AI's first investor and serial tech entrepreneur.

The Familia.AI app tackles three key areas of family dynamics and support:

AI-Powered Family Members for Emotional Support

Familia AI offers a lifeline to individuals who have experienced family-related challenges, including those from single-parent homes, those who lacked a supportive family environment, lost family members early, or endured other types of family trauma.

Dr. Emily Chen Ph.D., Familia.AI advisor and renowned psychologist specializing in family dynamics, commented: "Familia AI offers a unique opportunity for individuals to experience the kind of nurturing family interactions they may have missed, potentially helping to heal emotional wounds and family trauma."

Familia.AI App - Creating AI Family Personality



To view an enhanced version of this graphic, please visit:

https://images.newsfilecorp.com/files/10373/226387_e29ed86cb4d098f7_002full.jpg

Preserving Family Legacies for Future Generations

Serving as a digital family heirloom, Familia AI captures the essence, wisdom, and memories of real family members.

Bringing Lost Loved Ones to Life for Future Generations

Familia.AI can recreate the essence of family members that have passed, using old photos, video footage, and family anecdotes.

Familia.AI uses artificial intelligence to restore family photos, videos, written text, and even audio. This data is then used to create highly personalized AI family members that can engage in regular video messages, text messaging, voice calls and even participate in video calls. "Familia.AI's goal isn't to replace human connections, but to enhance where possible and preserve them," Luvaglio emphasized. "Familia.AI is using AI technology that allows families to bridge gaps of time and distance, offering support, preserving memories, and strengthening bonds across generations."

Story continues

Link Between Family Trauma & Loneliness

The launch of Familia.AI comes at a time when studies show an increasing need for emotional support and family connection:

67% of young adults report that problems at home or with parents have affected their mental health in later life [1].

42% of individuals attribute their struggles with forming healthy relationships to difficult family dynamics during childhood [2].

78% of therapy patients discuss family-related issues as a significant factor in their emotional challenges [3].

Recent research has highlighted the strong connection between family trauma and loneliness. A 2024 study found that individuals who experienced family trauma were 3.5 times more likely to report chronic loneliness in adulthood [4]. This loneliness has been linked to a range of negative health outcomes, including increased risk of depression, anxiety, and even physical health problems [5].

Dr. Chen elaborates, "Family trauma doesn't just affect our relationships with family members; it can fundamentally alter how we connect with others throughout our lives. Many individuals who've experienced family trauma struggle with trust, intimacy, and self-worth, which can lead to profound and persistent feelings of loneliness."

Familia.AI aims to address these challenges by providing a safe, supportive environment where users can experience positive family interactions, preserve cherished memories, and maintain connections with loved ones past and present. By doing so, the company is actively working to break cycles of family trauma, combat loneliness, and foster healthier emotional development across generations.

As the company looks to build on its unique AI family service, it remains committed to ethical AI development and user safety. "I believe Familia.AI is pioneering new territory in AI and I'm happy to support the business," says Luvaglio.

About Familia.AI

Familia.AI is an AI-powered app creating personalized digital family members that fill the gaps in family networks and preserve cherished family memories for future generations. By offering personalized family AI companions, Familia.AI's mission is to support and preserve human connections in an age where technology can be a force for emotional well-being.

References:

[1] Johnson, A. et al. (2023). Journal of Family Psychology, 37(4), 456-470.

[2] National Institute of Mental Health. (2022). NIMH Publication No. 22-MH-8234.

[3] American Psychological Association. (2024). APA Press.

[4] Smith, B. & Jones, C. (2024). Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 41(2), 189-205.

Media Contact

Dr. E. Chen

Familia.AI

press@familia.ai

To view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/226387

Generative AI tools are transforming business applications across various domains. The most prominent use cases include:

Fraud Detection and Security: Generative AI generates synthetic data to simulate fraudulent activities, improving the robustness of fraud detection models. This helps in enhancing cybersecurity measures and reducing the risk of cyber threats.

Rapid Software Development: AI tools like GitHub Copilot assist in code generation and error debugging, reducing development times and improving software quality.

Automated Content Creation: Generative AI automates the production of marketing and sales content, allowing teams to focus on strategic tasks.

Personalized Marketing: AI models analyze user data to generate personalized recommendations, enhancing customer engagement and driving sales.

Adaptive Product Design: Generative AI rapidly produces multiple product design iterations, helping businesses optimize their design processes and reduce time to market.

Supply Chain Optimization: AI models predict demand fluctuations and optimize delivery routes, resulting in more efficient supply chains and reduced operational costs.

Customer Service Automation: AI chatbots provide 24/7 support, handle complex queries, and guide customers through processes like product selection or troubleshooting.

Financial Modeling and Forecasting: Generative AI helps finance professionals create accurate models and forecasts, improving decision-making processes.

Lead Generation and Sales Automation: AI automates outreach, drafts personalized emails, and creates sales pitches, improving productivity and conversion rates.

Creative Content Generation: AI tools like DALL-E 2 and Midjourney generate compelling visuals and art, helping businesses produce engaging marketing content.

Generative AI tools in 2025 are driving innovation and operational efficiency across industries. From automating content creation to optimizing supply chains and enhancing customer experiences, these tools are becoming integral to business strategies. By leveraging these advanced AI solutions, businesses can stay ahead in a competitive market, improve productivity, and unlock new growth opportunities. The impact of generative AI is set to grow further as new tools and applications emerge, redefining what is possible in the business world.

title: Strange Possessions haunted exhibit opens through Laredo Paranormal Research Society, NeverDead Entertainment partnership
description: Uncover Laredo's haunted history at the Strange Possessions Exhibit, showcasing eerie relics and captivating stories at the ...
article_content:
Emma, the haunted antique doll, sits inside a box that will display her at the Strange Possessions Exhibit on Oct. 11. Courtesy/Jorge Vasquez

The Border Heritage Museum is partnering with NeverDead Entertainment and the Laredo Paranormal Research Society to publicly showcase local haunted artifacts for the first time.

For a little over three weeks, the museum will host the Strange Possessions Exhibit, which will house 20 relics with haunting backstories. The exhibit officially opened Friday at the Villa Antigua Border Heritage Museum, located at 810 Zaragoza St.

The Strange Possessions Exhibit opens Friday, showcasing "haunted artifacts" at the Border Heritage Museum through a partnership with NeverDead Entertainment and the Laredo Paranormal Research Society. Courtesy/Laredo Paranormal Research Society

NeverDead Entertainment founder Jesus Moreno says Laredo Paranormal Research Society founder Ismael Cuellar agreed to lend the relics from a collection of more than 200 items, which some believe to be cursed or possessed, that the society gathered over 30 years.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

“The paranormal, or stories of the paranormal, is such a huge part of our culture. These items even more so because they’re taken from homes here in Laredo,” Moreno said. “Some of these are from the historic Saint Peter’s area or other historic homes in Laredo.”

Cuellar said all except one item publicly debuted on Friday. The LPRS's well-known item, Emma — a plastic hillside doll with counter-weight eyes in a Victorian-era baby’s gown and hood — is making another appearance.

The doll came into the LPRS's possession in 2006 after an antique doll and curiosity collector complained of unexplained noises and occurrences in their home. After the society conducted an investigation, the LPRS said Emma appeared to blink and close its left eye after sitting in an isolated room for more than 40 hours.

Cuellar said he has presented Emma in public, with the LPRS later being asked to no longer bring her due to reports of flickering lights and strange sounds when she was present.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

Raggedy Andy, the possessed doll who doesn't enjoy being separate from its counterpart, Raggedy Ann. Courtesy/Jorge Vasquez

Raggedy Ann, the possessed doll who doesn't enjoy being separate from its counterpart, Raggedy Andy. Courtesy/Jorge Vasquez

Other items include a presumed witchcraft box that was found under a Laredo home, picture frames that are said to fly off the walls, and a pair of cloth Raggedy Ann and Andy dolls that reportedly refuse to be separated.

“Every time the family would leave the house, they would be in different areas of the house,” Cuellar said of the two dolls. “They separated the dolls, and then the following night, they found the dolls together. That was a big scare.”

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

Each artifact on display will showcase its background and the local stories or history that connect it to the area.

“The stories are very, very unique,” Cuellar said.

Pictured is the Border Heritage Museum, located at 810 Zaragoza St. in Laredo, Texas in 2023. Courtesy/WCHF

Moreno said that being able to display these items is an honor. “For (Cuellar) to trust us in displaying these artifacts and sharing the history, it’s a huge honor,” Moreno said. “Ultimately, it’s the point of research. We want to share what we found. We want to share the information we have available to us for future generations.”

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

NeverDead Entertainment and LPRS politely ask attendees to avoid touching the artifacts on display in order to preserve them and offer caution when being around Emma.

“Emma is the exception,” Moreno said. “There are extra precautions. She’s kept in a separate area.

“As long as people follow (the rules) and are safe about it, there shouldn’t be much of a problem or a danger for someone who wants to see the exhibit. But hey, if you’re religious or have any sort of belief, it doesn’t hurt to say a prayer before and after.”

title: Happenings in the lakes area, Oct. 12-23
description: Lakes Area Coffee Crawl: The 4th Annual Lakes Area Coffee Crawl will take place from 7 a.m.-2 p.m., at six different ...
article_content:
The Detroit Lakes Tribune accepts community calendar items for publication online and, space permitting, in our Wednesday and Saturday print editions. Submissions must be made at least a week in advance of the event date, in writing, to either dltribune@dlnewspapers.com or vgerdes@dlnewspapers.com. Each submission must include the date, time and location of event, and where to go for more information (phone, email and/or website). Also include whether the event is free or paid admission, and how much it costs when applicable.

Saturday, October 12

Lakes Area Coffee Crawl: The 4th Annual Lakes Area Coffee Crawl will take place from 7 a.m.-2 p.m., at six different locations in the lakes area including Fill Thy Cup, Ella Marie's, 908 Coffee and Tea, Monarch Coffee House, Roasted Pub, and Otter Coffee and Ice Cream. Tickets are available online for $25 each at eventbrite.com.

ADVERTISEMENT

"A Million Women" Livestream Event: Christian Fellowship Church in Detroit Lakes will host a livestream screening of "A Million Women: An Esther Call to the Mall," from 8 a.m.-6 p.m. Visit amillionwomen.org for more information.

Dynamic Homes Open House: The fall open house at Dynamic Homes in Detroit Lakes will take place from 9 a.m.-3 p.m. at 525 Roosevelt Ave., and will include the grand opening of their newest model home, The Laker. Come tour the local Dynamic Homes factory and model homes, enjoy refreshments, discover career opportunities and more. Free and open to the public.

Funky Junk Grand Opening: The new Funky Junk store at 109 W. Main St., Frazee, will host its grand opening at 10 a.m., with hot cocoa, cotton candy, popcorn, cupcakes and raffle prize drawings. Open to the public.

Lakes Variety Show Auditions: Detroit Lakes' Historic Holmes Theatre will be hosting auditions for the inaugural Lakes Variety Extravaganza from 10 a.m.-1 p.m. on the theater's main stage at 806 Summit Ave. All varieties of performance talent welcome. Please plan for your audition piece to last 3-5 minutes; the Holmes will be able to provide modest technical needs (microphones, follow spot, general lighting, etc.). Material must be family friendly (i.e., rated PG-13). Sign up for an audition time online at dlccc.org/holmes-theatre.html. Questions? Call Community Theater Coordinator Lorraine Bahr at 503-568-4017 or the Holmes Theatre at 218-844-7469.

Psychic-Paranormal-Wellness Fair: The Detroit Lakes Holiday Inn will host a Psychic, Paranormal and Wellness Fair from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Vendors may include tarot/oracle card readers, mediums, psychics, Reiki energy healers, shamans and reflexology; others will be selling crystals, stones, candles, jewelry, incense, and other merchandise. Admission is $5 per person, though children age 10 and under are admitted free of charge with a paid adult admission. Free gift bags for the first 30 people through the door. Open to the public.

Kids and Parents Expo: Detroit Lakes High School will host a Kids and Parents Expo from 9 a.m.-1 p.m., with activities including balloons and inflatables, spooky experiments and games, toy trucks come to life, a book walk and more. Tickets are $5 for parents, free for kids age 12 and under. Open to the public.

Marshmallow Hairball Fundraiser: The 12th Annual Hairball Fundraiser for the Marshmallow Animal Shelter and Boarding Facility will take place from 4-7 p.;m. at the Pit 611 Sports Bar and Grill, 15057 Co. Hwy. 11, Audubon. There will be food, live music from Tim Eggebraaten and Friends, a silent auction, raffles, and games of chance throughout the evening. Tickets, which include the meal and one complimentary drink token, are $30 in advance or $35 at the door. Advance tickets may be purchased at the Marshmallow Animal Shelter, 1478 Mallard St., Detroit Lakes, or online at marshmallowfoundation.org/info/events.

ADVERTISEMENT

Black Diamond Alpine Ski Teams Fundraiser: The 3rd Annual Black Diamond Fundraiser for Detroit Lakes' alpine ski teams will take place at VFW Post 1676, 500 Washington Ave., Detroit Lakes, from 5:30-9:30 p.m. Tickets are $50 per person, which includes the meal and two complimentary drink tokens.

Young Life 50th Anniversary: Lakes Area Young Life will be celebrating 50 years of youth ministry in the lakes area with a banquet in the Lakeshirts Field House at Detroit Lakes High School, 1301 Roosevelt Ave. The festivities begin with a 5 p.m. social hour, followed by the banquet at 6 p.m. Please RSVP via the website at lakesareayounglife.org/events to reserve your spot.

Bootlegger Bash: The Becker County Museum is hosting a Bootlegger Bash fundraiser, starting at 5 p.m. The museum will be transformed into a 1920s-era speakeasy for the fundraiser, which will include music from a seven-piece jazz band, live and silent auctions, food, a cash bar and more. Prohibition-era-themed attire is encouraged, but not required. Proceeds will go to support the museum's youth programming and completion of its capital campaign. Tickets are $65 each and may be purchased by phone at 218-847-2938 or online at beckercountyhistory.org/store.

Live Music: Rick Adams at The Roadhouse in Cormorant, 7:30 p.m.

Sunday, October 13

St. Andrew's Turkey Dinner: The congregation of St. Andrew's Catholic Church in Hawley invites the public to attend its annual fall dinner, which includes turkey with all the trimmings, assorted salads and desserts. Serving is from 11 a.m.-1:30 p.m.; cost is $15 for adults (age 13 and above) or $5 for kids ages 6-12; kids age 5 and under can eat for free. The church is located at 1418 Main St., Hawley. Catholic United Financial, Council 321 of Detroit Lakes will provide a matching grant of up to $500 for this fundraising event.

Tamarac Sunday Movie: A free screening of the family-friendly, nature-themed movie, "The Private Life of Deer," will be held at 2 p.m. in the Visitor Center at Tamarac National Wildlife Refuge. Take a peek into the world of deer. New investigations into their world reveal a more complex society than we imagined. They are smart, adaptable creatures, with impressive skills, senses, and family lives. Yet they also have unexpected shortcomings. Run time is approximately 55 minutes; all are welcome. Call 218-847-2641, visit fws.gov/refuge/tamarac or check the Refuge's Facebook page for more information on this event.

Lake Agassiz Wind Symphony: Songs and dances by Ralph Vaughan Williams, Dmitri Shostakovich, John Williams, Leonard Bernstein and more will be featured in "Songs and Dances," the season opening program by the Lake Agassiz Wind Symphony, which takes place at 3 p.m. inside Lake Park-Audubon High School, 611 Vigen Lane, Lake Park. Open to the public.

ADVERTISEMENT

Monday, October 14

Heart O'Lakes Harmony: The Heart O'Lakes Harmony men's barbershop-style a capella choral group is looking for new members. Anyone who enjoys singing is welcome to come join their weekly practices on Mondays at 7 p.m. in Faith Lutheran Church, 423 S. Broadway, Pelican Rapids (located across the street from the high school), starting Oct. 14. There will be a concert at 3 p.m. on Dec. 8 in Trinity Lutheran Church, Pelican Rapids. For more information please contact Harlan Hoff at 701-306-8976.

Tuesday, October 15

Old-Time Variety Dance: Eric's Dance Band will provide the music for an Old-Time Variety Dance, taking place from 1-4 p.m. at the Frazee Event Center. All are welcome; admission is $7 per person.

Tuesday Afternoon Book Club: Join the Detroit Lakes Library’s monthly Tuesday Afternoon Book Club at 3 p.m. for a lively discussion of the book, "The Scent Keeper" by Erica Bauermeister. "After getting jolted into the world from living on a remote island with only father and mysterious scents stored in paper, Emmeline must figure out her identity to understand her past" in this New York Times best seller. All are welcome, even if you haven't read the book. If you have any questions, feel free to email the library at detroit@larl.org or call 218-847-2168.

ECFE Night at the Museum: The Becker County Museum will host Detroit Lakes Early Childhood Family Education from 5:45-6:45 p.m. for some activities and opportunities to explore the museum. Open to families with infants, toddlers and preschool-age children. Sign up online at dlschools.arux.app if planning to attend.

Rotary Wine and Dine: The Detroit Lakes Breakfast Rotary will be hosting its annual wine and food pairing dinner at Spanky's Stone Hearth on Rose Lake (34785 Co. Hwy. 4, Frazee). Cash bar opens at 5:30 p.m., with dinner served at 6 pm. Tickets are $65 each and must be purchased in advance (tips not included). Enjoy a four-course, gourmet meal, paired with four different wines, selected to pair perfectly with each course. For ticket sales and more information, contact DLBreakfastRotary@gmail.com.

Thursday, October 17

Deep Dive DL: Join Project 412 at Maple Hills Orchard, 28355 130th St., Frazee, for a "Deep Dive DL" discussion with Maple Hills owners Gary and Jonna Goreham, who will share their journey in building a successful orchard business. Coffee and networking starts at 8 a.m., with the presentation set to get underway at 8:15 a.m. Free and open to the public. Visit mapklehillsorchard.com for more information prior to the presentation.

Youth Mental Health and Substance Abuse Summit: Calling all parents, guardians, caretakers, and professionals who are passionate about youth! Minnesota State Community and Technical College will be hosting a Youth Mental Health and Substance Abuse Summit from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Learn about suicide risk, how to prevent an opioid overdose, what Emmaus Crossroads is, a guide to find help and local community, and how to identify solutions to prevent substance use with youth.

ADVERTISEMENT

Harry Potter Trivia Event: Fans of the Harry Potter book series are invited to the Detroit Lakes Public Library at 2 p.m. for a magical trivia event! Questions will be based on the magical world first described in "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." Open to the public.

Painted Stones Remembrance Service: Hospice of the Red River Valley invites the community to join in a special remembrance service event designed to honor and celebrate the memory of loved ones. The “Painted Stones – A Remembrance Service” event at the Detroit Lakes Public Library, 1000 Washington Ave., will give participants the opportunity to paint stones as a meaningful tribute. After the 5:30 p.m. event, attendees can take home their painted stones as a lasting keepsake. The event is open to all community members of any age, and participation is free.F or further details and to register, please visit: https://bit.ly/griefclassschedule, or call 800-237-4629 and ask for the grief support department.

Mini Collage Workshop: Join artist Anna Lassonde at the Holmes Art Cellar, 806 Summit Ave. (basement level), Detroit Lakes, for a 6 p.m. class on "Sassy and Inspiring Mini Collages."

Friday, October 18

Live Music: Dan Brekke at the Sandbar in Detroit Lakes, 6:30-10 p.m.; Smokin' Amp DJ at the Detroit Lakes Holiday Inn, 9 p.m.-1 a.m.

Saturday, October 19

Permit to Carry Class: The Sandbar II Sports Bar and Cafe in Detroit Lakes will host a Minnesota Permit to Carry class from 9 a.m. to 2:30 p.m., taught by Red Bull Firearms Training. This class will cover the basic fundamentals of marksmanship, including how to load/unload your firearm, malfunction clearing, weapon retention and more. Cost is $80 for new students, $70 for renewals; lunch is included in the registration fee. Handgun rentals will also be available for $20. Call 218-234-7145 to register.

Eagles Club Crow Hunt: Come join Detroit Lakes Eagles Aerie 2342 for their annual crow hunt. Register a team of four, go shoot some crows. Bring them in to get counted and enjoy some time together with fellow shooters. Call 218-847-5267 or email eagles2342@hotmail.com for more information.

Live Music: Island Time at the Detroit Lakes VFW, 5-8 p.m. (part of Jim and Mary Ann Brogren's 60th anniversary celebration); Rachael Ianiro at the Toad Lake Store in rural Frazee, 7-10 p.m.; In the Fields at Zorbaz in Detroit Lakes, 9 p.m.-1 a.m.

ADVERTISEMENT

Sunday, October 20

Color Guard Fundraiser Breakfast: The Lake Region Veterans Color Guard will be hosting a breakfast fundraiser from 8 a.m.-12 p.m. at the American Legion Club, 810 West Lake Drive, Detroit Lakes. Suggested minimum donation is $8 for a meal including scrambled eggs; pancakes or French toast; sausage or bacon; and coffee or orange juice. All are welcome.

ULTRA Membership Drive and Dinner: The ULTRA Snowmobile Club will host a membership appreciation dinner and new member drive at Al's Bar and Grill/Audubon Liquors from 12-4 p.m. ULTRA will provide a complimentary pasta bar to every individual or family who signs up as a new member and/or renews their membership. A noon social hour will be followed by dinner at 1 p.m. and door prizes from 1-4 p.m. Bring a guest who joins as a new member for entry into a special drawing.

Monday, October 21

Ask a 'Techspert': Do you have a phone, tablet, laptop, iPad, Kindle or other device that you’re struggling to use? Visit the Detroit Lakes Public Library, 1000 Washington Ave., at 4 p.m. to learn more about your device, plus learn how to download eBooks and eAudiobooks free of charge.

Boo for Bunco PEO Fundraiser: Join the members of Detroit Lakes Philanthropic Education Organization (PEO) Chapter DQ at 5 p.m. the Detroit Lakes VFW (500 N. Washington Ave.) for a fun night of playing Bunco and contributing to the success of women by helping to fund PEO scholarships. Cost is $25 per person, which includes a meal at 5:30 p.m., followed by Bunco at 6 p.m. No experience is necessary to win prizes, and there will also be a silent auction. Please register by Oct. 17. Sign up online at bit.ly/3Zl5iM1 or by mailing your check to Chapter DQ, P.E.O., 13027 Red Elm Ridge, Audubon MN 56511.

Traveling Art Pub: Come to Hub 41 in Detroit Lakes from 6-8:30 p.m. for an evening of guided painting with the Traveling Art Pub. Bring home your very own, 16x20 acrylic painting on canvas, with "Cutie-Boo-Tootie" as the inspiration. Tickets must be purchased in advance; cost is $43.50 per person (no refunds), which includes all supplies and service fees. Sign up online at thetravelingart.pub.com to reserve your spot.

Tuesday, October 22

Library Club with Kent Mollberg: The Detroit Lakes Library Club invites the public to come join them for a 2 p.m. discussion with information technology specialist Kent Mollberg on "Top Tips for Avoiding Scams and Identity Theft." Mollberg will address the most common scams out there and how to avoid them. The intended audience is adults with an emphasis on the elderly who appear to be the most vulnerable to these scams. Feel free to come early to enjoy a cup of coffee and treat while getting to know others who are curious about our community and its people. All are welcome.

Becker County Friends of the Library Meeting: Join the Becker County Friends of the Library at the Detroit Lakes Public Library (1000 Washington Ave.) at 4 p.m. and learn how to help support the library's services in your community. All are welcome to attend and get involved.

ADVERTISEMENT

"Credit Reports and Scores" Seminar: Join Nicole Pfeffer, community outreach manager at Mid Minnesota Federal Credit Union in Detroit Lakes, for a 5 p.m. financial education seminar on "Credit Reports and Scores" at the Lincoln Education Center, 204 E. Willow St., Detroit Lakes. Get answers to questions like, "What is a credit report?" and "How is a credit score determined" in this free one-hour workshop hosted by Detroit Lakes Community Education. There is no cost to attend, but please register by contacting the DL Community Ed office at 218-847-4418, or sign up online at dlschools.arux.app to reserve your spot.

Spooky Upcycled Painting Class: Come to the Holmes Art Cellar in the basement of the Historic Holmes Theatre, 806 Summit Ave., Detriot Lakes, for a 5:30 p.m. painting class and learn to upcycle an old painting into your own Halloween-inspired fall landscape by adding cute little elements like ghosts, bats, pumpkins and more. There will be a selection of paintings to choose from, but feel free to bring your own if you have an image in mind. You'll leave class with a framed Halloween masterpiece. Intended for ages 16 and up; cost is $55 per person, which includes all supplies and instruction for the class. Sign up online at dlccc.org/artcellar.html or call 218-844-7469 to reserve your spot, as space is limited.

Wednesday, October 23

Open Acoustic Jam: Bring your acoustic instruments to the Detroit Lakes Public Library for an unplugged jam session, starting at 5 p.m. All experience levels are welcome to this supportive and family-friendly event. Free and open to the public. Bring your acoustic instrument and come have some fun!

Pinot for Paws: The Humane Society of the Lakes is hosting a "Pinot for Paws" fundraiser at Spanky's Stone Hearth, 34785 Co. Ywy. 4, Frazee, with a 5:30 p.m. social followed by a four-course dinner with wine pairings, starting at 6 p.m. Cost is $100 per person, or $180 for a pair of tickets. Reservations are required, and there are a limited number of seats available. Please register online at humanesocietyofthelakes.org to reserve your spot.

Multi-day and Recurring Events

Break the Silence Memorial Display: The Detroit Lakes City Park will host a "Break the Silence Memorial Display" from Oct. 1-13 — the first two weeks of Domestic Violence Awareness Month. The display, sponsored by the Lakes Crisis and Resource Center of Detroit Lakes, is a series of 30 silhouettes that serve as a virtual representation of Minnesota's victims of intimate partner homicide, with each representing someone's child, parent, sibling, husband, wife, partner, friend, neighbor or coworker. Come to the Detroit Lakes City Park to learn about, remember, and honor each victim. There will be event booklets available at the park as well as at LCRC's offices on Pelican Lane, and each silhouette will also have a QR code that you can scan with your smartphone to obtain more in-depth information on each victim.

Walk for the Wild: Are you looking for a way to combine fitness and pet exercise with a good cause? Sign up for the Walk for the Wild 5K Challenge happening during National Wildlife Refuge Week, Oct. 12-20, at Tamarac National Wildlife Refuge. The walk begins at the Pine Lake parking lot on Highway 29 at Tamarac Refuge, just south of the visitor center. Just follow the signs around the Tamarac Loop and take the short spur trail up and back to make it a 5K walk. Stop by the Visitor Center on Saturday or Sunday, Oct. 12-13 between 10 a.m.-5 p.m. to have your dog be sworn in as a Bark Ranger and receive their official Bark Ranger dog tag. Registration is free and you can walk any time Oct. 12-20, with or without a pet. Bark Ranger tags are only available during open hours of the center. Sign up online at americaswildliferefuges.org/walk-for-the-wild to show your support.

Haunted Hill: The Becker County Museum is partnering with Detroit Mountain Recreation Area for the museum's 5th Annual Haunt. The Haunted Hill will take place outdoors at Detroit Mountain on two successive weekends, Oct. 18-19 and Oct. 25-26, from 7-9 p.m. each night. Intended for those age 13 and up; anyone younger must be accompanied by an adult (with paid admission). Cost is $20 cash, per person, regardless of age, and must be paid at the gate. Please dress appropriately for outdoor weather and trail walking. Groups limited to six people; larger groups will be split. No pictures or video permitted. Call the museum at 218-847-2938 for more information.

Haunted Forest: The CornerStone Youth and Community Center will host its second annual Haunted Forest event at 35646 154th St.Frazee on Oct. 18-19. First scare will start at 6:30 p.m., with the final tour starting at 10:30 p.m. Cost is $10 per person, or $50 maximum per family. Call 218-329-6199 for more information.

American Adventure Exhibit: The Becker County Museum in Detroit Lakes will be hosting the traveling exhibit, "American Adventure," through May 24, 2025. This 3,000-square-foot, interactive history exhibit will be located on the museum's basement level, and consists of a realistic, "choose-your-adventure" maze where visitors can learn about one of America's earliest pioneer settlements, Jamestown, Virginia, and see if they have what it takes to survive under the conditions that the settlers experienced back in 1607. The exhibit will be at the museum through the end of the 2024-25 school year. General admission is $20 for adults, $10 for kids (museum members receive a 50% discount). There are also group rates and pre-visit lesson plans available for student tours. Hours are 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Tuesday through Saturday. Contact the museum at 218-847-2938 or visit the exhibit's Facebook event page for more information.

Farmers Market: The Lakes Area Farmers Market will be open every Tuesday and Saturday through the end of October in Detroit Lakes' Peoples Park from 10 a.m.-1 p.m. Come shop with your favorite returning vendors, or discover some new ones, until 1 p.m. Vendors accept EBT cards and food checks to be used for fresh fruit and vegetables. Go to lakesareafarmersmarket.info for more information.

Janu's Pumpkin Patch: Opening day at Janu's Pumpkin Patch, located at 50617 404th Ave., Frazee, is set for Saturday, Oct. 5. The pumpkin patch will also be open on Sunday, Oct. 6, as well as both Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 12-13, from 9 a.m.-5 p.m. each day. Come search for the perfect pumpkin to bring home, and enjoy some other fun fall activities, including hay rides and more. Open to the public.

Women Create Exhibit: The New York Mills Regional Cultural Center’s new gallery exhibit, “Women Create,” will be displayed through Oct. 12, showcasing the work of three local painters and sculptors, including Linda Beilke of Frazee, and Linda Sheryak and Donna Chalimonczyk of Moorhead. The paintings and sculptures in “Women Create” will be available for purchase, though the exhibit itself is free and open to the public. Hours are 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m.-7 p.m. Fridays and 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturdays. Private viewings can be arranged anytime by calling Cheryl Bannes at 218-385-3339 or emailing cheryl@kulcher.org. For more information, visit kulcher.org or call the Cultural Center at 218-385-3339.

Otter Berry Corn Maze: Come to Otter Berry Farm in rural New York Mills and enjoy its 6-acre, interactive corn maze, with over 50 varieties of pumpkins, gourds and squash along with tons of fun activities for the whole family, including a petting zoo, tractors to climb on, and plenty of games to play. The maze will be open every Saturday and Sunday through Oct. 27 and is handicap accessible. Hours are 11 a.m.-5:30 p.m. Saturdays, and 1-5 p.m. Sundays. Extended hours during MEA weekend, Oct. 18-20. No smoking, and no pets allowed. Visit otterberryfarm.com/corn-maze-pumpkin-patch for more information.

Sleeping Bags Needed: The Holy Rosary Knights of Columbus in Detroit Lakes are collecting sleeping bags for distribution to those in need. Anyone who has a new or used, functional sleeping bag (i.e., the zipper works) can drop them off at the Becker County Food Pantry, 610 Terry St., Detroit Lakes, anytime between 8 a.m.-3 p.m. on Tuesdays and Thursdays. For more information contact Brad Carlson at 218-234-4448.

Grace Cafe: Grace Lutheran Church in Detroit Lakes will be serving lunch every Wednesday from 12-1 p.m. The lunch is open to all in the Detroit Lakes area; admission is a free-will donation. Guests are welcome to stay after the meal to play games or cards.

Grace Food Pantry: Grace Lutheran Church in Detroit Lakes will be operating a food pantry during its regular office hours, 9 a.m.- noon Monday through Friday. Anyone in need can come in and pick up some food. Donations will also be accepted.

Library Storytime: The Detroit Lakes Public Library offers weekly Preschool Storytime sessions every Thursday at 10:30 a.m. Preschoolers and their caregivers/families are invited to join library staff for stories, flannel boards, finger plays, songs and more. This early literacy experience explores a different theme each week and is a way to encourage young children to enjoy reading. Call 218-847-2168 for more information.

Celebrate Recovery: The Celebrate Recovery group meets every Tuesday, 6:30-8 p.m. at Christian Fellowship Church, 28048 Meadow Drive, Detroit Lakes, to take the next steps on the "Road to Recovery: Eight Principles Based on the Beatitudes, Twelve Steps and their Biblical Comparison." Many struggle with alcoholism, divorce, sexual abuse, codependency, domestic violence, drug addiction, food and gambling addictions. Celebrate Recovery is a tried and proven format to help you walk through life's struggles. Men and women meet in a large group format, then break off into smaller discussion groups; men with men, women with women. Come as you are. No cost. We are here to help. Unfortunately, no childcare is available at this time. For more information, check out the website at celebraterecovery.com or call us at 218-234-2496.

Caring Cup Grief Support: The Caring Cup, a gathering of community members who are dealing with the loss of a loved one, will meet at the David-Donehower Funeral Home in Detroit Lakes on the second Wednesday of every month; the Furey Funeral Home in Frazee on every third Wednesday, and West-Kjos Funeral Home in Detroit Lakes on every fourth Wednesday. All meetings take place from 10:30 to 11:30 a.m., and offer a relaxed time to face the challenges of life after loss, together. For more information, call Mary Swenson at 218-847-4147.

TOPS Meeting: The local chapter of Take Off Pounds Sensibly (TOPS) meets weekly on Thursday mornings at Trinity Lutheran Church, 1401 Madison Ave., Detroit Lakes. Weigh-in begins at 8:20 a.m., meeting at 9 a.m. Contact Carol at 218-841-0226 or Coleen at 218-841-2877 for more information. All are welcome; first session is free.

Trivia Nights: Lakeside Tavern in Detroit Lakes hosts a Trivia Night every Monday from 7 to 9 p.m. Event takes place in Lakeside Tavern's upstairs space, so seating is limited. Open to the public.

GED/Adult Diploma Instruction: If finishing high school is still on your “to-do” list, it is never too late!! Lakes Area Adult Education is open and ready to help you meet your goals. Orientation sessions for GED or Adult Diploma classes take place twice a month, so get in touch and get started now! Call 218-844-5760 or email slandsem@detlakes.k12.mn.us. Additional Adult Education offerings and associated flyers can always be found at dlschools.net/departments/community-education.

Free ESL Instruction: Free English as a Second Language instruction is offered for adults in the Detroit Lakes Area, every Monday through Thursday (holidays excepted) at Lakes Area Adult Education. The schedule is flexible and individualized. Call 218-844-5760 or email slandsem@detlakes.k12.mn.us for more information. Additional Adult Education offerings and associated flyers can always be found at dlschools.net/departments/community-education.

Minnesota Driver's License Exam Preparation: Detroit Lakes Adult Basic Education offers virtual classes that are designed to help unlicensed adult drivers become familiar with vocabulary, signs and rules of the road so they can successfully pass the written portion of the Minnesota Driver’s License Exam. Call 218-844-5760 or email slandsem@detlakes.k12.mn.us for more information. Additional Adult Education offerings and associated flyers can always be found at communityed.dlschools.net.

DL Cloggers: The DL Cloggers meet to dance and socialize every Tuesday (excluding holidays) at 1 p.m. in the basement of Detroit Lakes VFW Post 1676. No prior dance experience necessary. For more information, call Ruby at 218-847-7741.

HR Connect: The Detroit Lakes Chamber is hosting an opportunity for human resources professionals, business owners and managers to connect, every first Thursday of the month at 8:15 a.m. at the Chamber office at 700 Summit Ave. Discuss human resource topics, share best practices and review data to help attract, retain and grow the workforce for the lakes region. Event is free for Chamber members, $10 for non-members.

Baby Bounce: Songs, stories, and action poems for infants, toddlers and their caregivers are offered every Monday at the Detroit Lakes Public Library at 10:30 a.m. Program runs about a half hour including playtime and chatting with other caregivers. For ages 0-18 months. Call 218-847-2168 for more information.

Alcoholics Anonymous: Detroit Lakes' Alano Club meets at 827 Summit Ave. on the following days and times: Sundays at 1 p.m., 12x12 open meeting; Tuesdays at 7 p.m., Big Book open meeting; Wednesdays at noon, Grapevine open meeting; Wednesdays at 6 p.m., women's open meeting; Thursdays at 7 p.m., Intro to AA open meeting; Saturdays at 7 a.m., men's open meeting; Saturdays at 9 a.m., Women's Big Book closed meeting; Saturdays at 8 p.m., open topic meeting. There are no dues or fees for meetings. For more information, call 218-844-9970 or the District 3 AA Helpline at 877-833-2327.

Holy Rosary Al-Anon Meeting: There will be an Al-Anon meeting every Thursday, starting at noon, inside Holy Rosary Catholic Church, 1043 Lake Ave., Detroit Lakes. There is also an Al-Anon meeting at 7 p.m. every Tuesday at the Alano Club at 827 Summit Ave. in Detroit Lakes.

Overeaters Anonymous: A 12-step program for those who struggle in their relationship with food, Overeaters Anonymous continues to meet at noon every Tuesday at Holy Rosary Catholic Church in Detroit Lakes. There is no charge to attend. Contact Debbie C. at 218-234-3071. Another group also meets on Sunday nights at 6 p.m. via Zoom. This is a change of venue as of Oct. 9. Please call Sharon R. at 1-701-388-7585 or Hailee S. at 1-701-212-7904 for information if you plan to join the Zoom meeting. There is no charge to participate.

Compiled by Vicki Gerdes for the Detroit Lakes Tribune.

title: Men won all the science Nobels this year. There’s an even bigger problem
description: The men who received this year’s prizes are 'superstars,' said Liselotte Jauffred, a physicist at the Niels Bohr Institute ...
article_content:
Since the Nobel Prizes were created in 1901, just 24 women have received awards in the sciences. This year, that number stayed the same: All seven laureates in physics, chemistry, and physiology or medicine were men.

Some scientists have expressed frustration about the lack of women among this year’s awardees, particularly the omission of two women who contributed to the work honored for the prize in physiology or medicine. Experts who study gender bias in the sciences say the Nobel’s gender gap reflects the larger barriers to success faced by women in science — and that science is poorer for it.

advertisement

The men who received this year’s prizes are “superstars,” said Liselotte Jauffred, a physicist at the Niels Bohr Institute who has studied gender bias in the Nobels. But “what are the mechanisms that make it easier for men to enter that pool of superstar scientists that could even be nominated for a Nobel Prize?”

Certain fields, like biology, chemistry and social sciences are reaching gender parity in undergraduate and graduate degrees. But representation falls further up the academic ladder — a problem known as the leaky pipeline. Some women are pushed out of science altogether because of experiences of sexism. Those who persist are less often promoted to senior professorships, and even fewer become chief physicians, department heads, or journal editors.

Even once in academia, women are not given tenure as often as men. They are not listed as the key author on as many papers, are cited less often than male colleagues, and receive fewer prestigious awards overall.

advertisement

Figuring out whether the Nobels reflect even more bias than academia as a whole was “not easy” Jauffred said. Researchers had to account for the lag between when a discovery is made and when it is recognized, and for the lower representation of women in science over the years. But even when accounting for those factors, she and her colleagues found in a 2019 study that the likelihood that bias against women played a role in the decision of who gets awards was around 96%.

This year’s Nobel for physiology or medicine, which was awarded to Gary Ruvkun and Victor Ambros for the discovery of microRNA, has attracted particular scrutiny with regard to gender bias. Many outside observers commented on the fact that Rosalind Lee, Ambros’ wife and long-time collaborator, was not recognized for the discovery despite being a first author on one of the studies cited by the committee. To some, the story seemed to write itself — another Rosalind overlooked by the committee, much like Rosalind Franklin, whose contributions to the discovery of DNA’s double helix were not initially recognized.

There are, however, reasons beyond sexism that can lead collaborators like Lee to get overlooked. The Nobel committee limits awards to three people, which some scientists have pointed out is an antiquated way to reward discoveries that are increasingly part of large collaborations.

“Any project of any complexity rolls out over years with many contributors,” said Bruce Wightman, a biologist at Muhlenberg College who was in Ruvkun’s lab and worked on an aspect of the discovery of microRNA. “Science takes a village.”

A spokesperson for UMass Chan Medical School said Lee and Ambros are “celebrating the Nobel Prize and view it as a recognition of the team’s collaborative work.”

The push to reduce gender bias in Nobel Prizes

That said, how credit is distributed to scientists that are part of a large collaboration may also be the product of bias. One study found that women who co-authored papers were less likely to receive tenure compared to those who published papers alone. This kind of collaboration didn’t have any effect on men’s ability to get tenure. Another found that women tended to receive authorship on papers or patents to which they had contributed less often than male colleagues.

advertisement

The Nobels tend to “recognize people who were in a position of power and authority, instead of the people who actually made a discovery or had an idea or proved it experimentally,” said Pnina Abir-Am, a historian of science at Brandeis University, who has studied collaborative couples in science as well as documented the women who were not recognized for the Nobel prize for RNA splicing.

Sign Up Your data will be processed in accordance with our Privacy Policy and Terms of Service. You may opt out of receiving STAT communications at any time.

The Nobel committee is often “narrow-minded” in who it gives awards to, Abir-Am said, favoring those who are heads of the lab where the research was conducted as well as those who have trained with other Nobel laureates. That means lower chances of receiving the prize for women, racial minorities, and more junior scientists who have made breakthrough discoveries but are less likely to be in positions of power.

Nobel winners also tend to come from socioeconomically privileged backgrounds, according to Paul Novosad, an economist at Dartmouth College who studies access to opportunity and upward mobility. Novosad and his colleagues published a white paper this week finding that on average, laureates came from households with fathers in the 87th percentile of income in their country. Around half were in the top 5% by income.

Female laureates tended to be from even more elite families, which the authors write may be because the higher socioeconomic status helps them overcome some of the gendered obstacles in academia. But “it means that elite women in the sciences are drawn from an even smaller socioeconomic pool than men, implying substantial misallocation,” they write in the paper.

“If children who are brilliant but poor fail to make it into the sciences, then all of humanity loses out on their potential discoveries,” said Novosad.

Things may be changing. The analysis found that the average socioeconomic status of laureates is creeping downward, which could signal a slow democratization of the sciences. “This kind of research is really important for the same reasons that we would like to see less elite demographics represented in various top positions,” said Novosad. “Unfortunately there is still a surprising amount of work to do just to convince men in senior scientific positions that these barriers exist at all.”

advertisement

One change that may make recognition more fair going forward is the growing practice of papers delineating what each author has contributed to a paper. “Journals require scientists to say who contributed to conception and who contributed to experiments,” Abir-Am said. This creates less ambiguity around who directly contributed to discoveries that are being honored by awards — as opposed to assuming lab heads or senior authors did the lion’s share of the work. “I don’t care who is a director and who is a junior [researcher], I want to know who did what.”

The organizations that select Nobel laureates have taken steps to address the laureates’ lack of diversity in recent years. In 2019, Nobel committees began asking nominators to consider gender and ethnicity to encourage a wider range of diversity in nominees. And since scientists have to be invited to contribute nominations, “[w]e are extending invitations to an increasing number of individuals from regions beyond traditional academic research hubs in the United States, Europe, Australia and Japan,” Thomas Perlmann, the secretary for the Nobel Committee for Physiology or Medicine, told Nature this week. “Moreover, we’re actively identifying more women and younger scientists as nominators.”

Jauffred has also seen improvement. She was motivated to write her paper on gender bias in the Nobels after Donna Strickland in 2018 became the first woman to win the Nobel in physics in 55 years. Since 2018, two more women have also won the Nobel in physics. Still, progress is slow.

“The demography of fields has been changing for a long time, but it’s not yet reflected in Nobel Prizes,” Jauffred said. “When we don’t see that diversity represented in the Nobel Prizes, of course we ask ourselves questions. Why does it have to be like that?”

Megan Molteni contributed reporting.

title: Nobel Prize winner hopes his discovery can help fight disease and even detect alien life
description: Gary Ruvkun says microRNA, which are molecules that control how genes form our cells, could be the key to improving how ...
article_content:
Quirks and Quarks 10:29 A Nobel prize for understanding how genes are turned on and off

Gary Ruvkun says microRNA, which are molecules that control how genes form our cells, could be the key to improving how humans fight diseases, and even finding extraterrestrial signs of life.

On Monday, the Nobel Prize in Medicine or Physiology was awarded to Ruvkun and his colleague Victor Ambros for their discovery in 1993 of a previously unrecognized group of molecules — dubbed microRNA — which help control which genes are active and when. This plays a vital role in how complex life forms grow and function.

Gary Ruvkun is a professor of genetics at Harvard Medical School. He spoke with Quirks & Quarks host Bob McDonald about his life-changing discovery, and how he hopes to use RNA to find life on other planets. Here is part of that conversation.

What was it like to get that call from Stockholm?

It's been sort of in play for about 20 years. And so at four in the morning when the phone rings, it sort of took a minute to register, and my wife answered it and she said, "He has a Swedish accent!" Then it was like, "Oh!"

Tell me the story of how we started to understand how genes get turned on and off, [which] led to your work on microRNA.

So this emerged from doing genetic analysis in this little [worm called a] nematode. So the nematode is a big part of the ecosystem in soils, and it's so simple, it has 959 cells and every cell has a name. So I started to work in 1982, as did Victor Ambros, and we worked together on the pedigree of cells that generates the animal.

How did that lead to the discovery of the role of microRNA?

When we figured out what these genes were, it turned out one of them encoded a product that was about five times smaller than any gene had ever been seen to be. It was only 25 nucleotides (the building blocks of RNA and DNA) long. And that was a new phenomenon, and it was considered kind of a quirk, and it wasn't clear what it really meant.

Nobel Committee Secretary General Thomas Perlmann speaks to the media in front of a picture of this year's laureates Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun during the announcement of the winners of the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. (Jonathan Nackstrand/Getty Images)

When did you realize that this was a brand new genetic molecule?

This is early days. We didn't have any genomes at this point but within five years, genomes were emerging. The way we figured out that [microRNA was present in the human genome] was we got a second one of these microRNAs, these very small genes, and that one had a human [equivalent], and got an answer by comparing the worm genome with its 25 letters, and there were those same 25 letters in the human genome.

What do these microRNAs actually do?

They regulate other target genes, and they do all kinds of different processes, and they are used in essentially every animal and every plant. So they're as ancient as the divergence of plants and animals, which is, you know, a billion years ago. And have been implicated in, for example, the domestication of corn 5000 years ago.

These mutations are what the Indigenous peoples selected for. They didn't know they were doing that, but they got what are called heterochronic mutants, mutants that do things differently when they're developing. And that's what makes bigger corn cobs.

I understand that more recently, you've been applying your knowledge for the search for microbial life outside of our solar system. Tell me about that.

Yeah, that's been a passion. So we sort of dove into the richness of RNA biology, and there's a long tradition of people trying to figure out how the ribosome works, for example.

And the ribosome is the tiny machine in all of our cells that takes messenger RNA and translates them into proteins, and it turns out that the key element of the ribosome is an RNA that probably existed before proteins even evolved.

That RNA is the most conserved thing on Earth, and it's how biologists all over the world go to bizarre ecosystems like snow and ice, or ponds, or deep in the ocean, or human feces, you name it. You can look for who's in there by looking for the DNA segments that are present in the ribosome.

Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun speak onstage during the Breakthrough Prize Awards Ceremony in 2014. Their discovery of microRNA in 1993 has completely transformed what we know about how cells work. (Steve Jennings/Getty Images for Breakthrough Prize)

And so I've been trying to convince NASA that that's how they should look for life on Mars, and their response is always, "Well, yes, but that's a very Earth centred view of looking for life. Are you stupid?" And my response is, it'd be stupid to not first look for that.

If you think that Mars is going to have independently evolved life, that's stupid, because of course it's going to spread between Earth and Mars. They're right near each other, and there's meteoritic exchange between the two. We have Martian meteorites on Earth, not a lot of them, but you don't need a lot to have bacteria move between planetary systems.

Are there any future applications of microRNA research that you're hoping to see?

Yeah. I mean, we're going to continue to work on sort of, what are the pathways right now. One of the big things we do is we now know a lot about what are the proteins that are involved in presenting these tiny RNAs to their targets.

And we know that some of those proteins, they're not present in humans or most of the animal kingdom, but the worm has them, ticks and spiders have them, coral has them, and these are the organisms that do antiviral defence way better than we do.

So we're trying to figure out why so many of the animals like most insects, all of the vertebrates, essentially dumped their very ancient antiviral pathway to develop what's called the interferon pathway, which is how we fight viruses. And my view is that we don't do such a good job in comparison.

title: The Future of Data Security in Fintech: Trends and Solutions
description: The fintech industry has significantly transformed over the past decade, driven by technological advancements and changing ...
article_content:
The fintech industry has significantly transformed over the past decade, driven by technological advancements and changing consumer preferences. The need for robust security measures for fintech companies has never been more critical. Fintech companies continue to innovate making data security a top priority.

Over the years, fintech security has evolved to include various technologies and practices, including virtual data room solutions. Today, these technologies develop, offering new ways to protect financial transactions and sensitive data. This article will explore the future of data security in fintech from the data room perspective.

Understanding fintech and the role of data security

Fintech, meaning financial technology, refers to technology integration into financial services to improve the delivery of financial products. Fintech companies needed advanced security measures to protect their customers’ sensitive data. The transformation of fintech security has been forced by the need to stay ahead of cybercriminals while providing compliance with regulatory requirements.

Data security in the fintech sector involves technologies, processes, and best practices for protecting sensitive financial data. It includes data security protocols, compliance with regulations, and ongoing security risk monitoring. The main goal of data security is to prevent unauthorised access and safeguard against data breaches and other cyber attacks.

Virtual data room software for fintech data security

A virtual data room (VDR) is a digital space where important documents and information are stored and shared. It lets authorised users access and work together on files for business activities. Maintaining security is paramount because of the nature of the data stored in VDRs. Data breaches can lead to a competitive edge, legal repercussions, and harm to reputation.

Security measures are crucial for safeguarding data and upholding compliance standards within virtual data rooms. For enhanced protection, dataroom software employs security functionalities such as encryption, access controls, audit trails, and device restrictions. The important and sensitive data stored in VDRs needs security to stop cyber threats. Ensuring security in VDRs is crucial for keeping things private following the rules and avoiding problems.

“Investing in a secure data storage place will reap the rewards in many ways,” says Gilbert Waters, Co-founder and marketing specialist at data-rooms.org. The organization of VDR security starts with choosing among data room providers known for data protection. Ensure they hold security certifications such as ISO 27001 and undergo independent audits. Avoid providers that don’t specify their security architecture or protocols.

Key VDR security elements

Virtual data rooms utilise a layered approach to security, with multiple critical elements working together to protect sensitive data. Some of the key elements include:

Data encryption . It is crucial for all data stored and sent via a data room to be encrypted using recognised methods, like AES 256-bit encryption . This process transforms data into a code that can only be decoded with the encryption key. Multi-factor authentication . It mandates users to present two or more credentials for access, such as a password paired with a one-time code or biometric verification. This strategy safeguards against password compromise and unauthorised entry. Advanced virtual data rooms support MFA techniques like SMS codes, authenticator apps, and biometric identifiers. Access controls . Granular user permissions allow tight control over document storage and access. Admins can restrict viewing, downloading, printing, watermarking, and other actions on a user and document group basis. Complex access regulations based on user attributes can be configured. Audit trails track all user activity.

Fintech data security trends

Technology integration transforms and reshapes data security management and how financial institutions operate. Here are the main trends that influence and shape data security:

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) . They have changed financial services, helping in fraud detection, threat intelligence, and transaction analysis. Artificial intelligence technologies leverage algorithms to analyse data and identify patterns and potential security threats that might go unnoticed by traditional methods.

Biometric technologies . It includes facial recognition and fingerprint scanning, which are increasingly used in fintech applications to enhance security. These technologies provide a higher level of protection compared to traditional methods. Biometric authentication enhances data privacy by ensuring access to financial accounts only to authorised users.

Blockchain technology . Blockchain uses a distributed ledger that records transactions across a network of nodes. Each transaction is secured cryptographically and linked to the previous one, forming a chain resistant to tampering. This immutability is essential for maintaining data integrity and ensuring compliance with privacy regulations.

Cloud technology . Cloud computing enhances data privacy in several ways. It uses advanced encryption techniques to secure data at rest and in transit. Strict access controls allow companies to define who can access specific data and under what conditions, further bolstering privacy. Advanced threat detection and response mechanisms are integral to cloud services, helping identify security breaches.

Conclusion

As the fintech landscape evolves, ensuring robust security measures is more crucial than ever. Fintech security is a critical element in the fintech industry, as the sector faces many challenges. By adopting innovative technologies financial institutions can protect sensitive customer data, mitigate risks, and build trust with their customers. Using data rooms, in particular, can provide a relevant tool for maintaining data security and compliance in the fintech sector. Leveraging virtual data rooms for sensitive data companies must partner with providers who actively invest in the latest security innovations and stay ahead of emerging risks.

title: Digital Arrest: A New Form of Online Fraud
description: Digital arrest is a new form of online fraud where scammers use video conferencing and deepfake technology to trick ...
article_content:
A disturbing new trend has emerged in the world of cybercrime: digital arrest. In this type of scam, victims are tricked into believing they are under a “virtual” arrest and are coerced into staying connected with the scammer through video conferencing software.

Similar to phishing scams, digital arrest involves deceiving individuals into revealing sensitive information. However, these scams are more sophisticated, often employing AI-generated audio and video to create a convincing facade of legitimacy.

The scammers typically dangle the threat of severe consequences, such as financial loss or legal action, to manipulate their victims. Many victims are lulled into a false sense of security by the use of video conferencing software, which can make the scam seem more authentic.

The use of deepfake technology allows scammers to impersonate real individuals, making it difficult for victims to discern the authenticity of the video call. This adds a layer of complexity and credibility to the scam, making it more difficult to detect.

Once victims are trapped in the digital arrest scenario, they are subjected to a variety of demands. Scammers may request personal information, financial details, or even demand payments to avoid further consequences. Victims may be coerced into staying connected for extended periods, effectively holding them hostage to the scammer’s demands.

It is important to be aware of the tactics used by scammers in digital arrests. By understanding the common techniques employed, individuals can better protect themselves from falling victim to these scams.

Key Points

Digital arrests involve tricking victims into believing they are under a virtual arrest.

Scammers use video conferencing software and deepfake technology to create a convincing facade.

Victims are coerced into staying connected and revealing sensitive information.

It is crucial to be aware of these scams and take precautions to protect yourself.
